content.description: Sit start at the left of the cave beneath the long rail feature. Your right hand will be on a small crimp and your left on the bottom of the one pad rail feature. Make a cruxy move to get your right hand onto the rail, and then continue upwards to the big, diagonal, jug rail. Here the difficulty tapers off as you pop up to a good hold on the arete and then surf it to final lip and an easy mantel.
content.location: It climbs the left side of the face sitting in the cave beneath the rail feature.

content.description: Stand or sit start towards the right side of the face on the lower of two parallel cracks, on mini-crimps/pockets. I had my left hand on a three finger, half pad pocket and my right hand on a two finger, third pad abomination. Rock onto your right foot, and reach up to hit a good crimp rail. Don't let your feet slip as you step up, and then go for the lip to top out.
content.location: It is on the right side of the face in the lower of the parallel cracks on small crimps/pockets of your choice about two feet left of the left-facing, vertical, sidepull rail.

content.description: Stand start the boulder at the center of the face on two good, four finger pockets in the crack. With good foot holds, make a move up and right to a good crimp rail. Step the feet up, and then fire your left hand for the lip. Match your right hand, and then mantel it out. This is a great warm-up. It was first ascended in eight degrees below zero with the wind chill!
content.location: Climb the center of the face.

content.description: The Oasis has a South-facing, vertical face looking towards a beautiful, small pond. Towards the left of the face is a small overhung section. There are about six unique routes on the face.This is a good one to hit if there has been recent rain, because it gets a lot of sun and tends to dry rather quickly.
